project_metadata.paper_title: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Cooperative Deployment of a Generalized, Archaeology-Specific Field Data Collection System
project_metadata.journal: In: Mobilizing the Past for a Digital Future: The Potential of Digital Archaeology, edited by Erin Walcek Averett, Jody Michael Gordon, and Derek B. Counts, pp. 337-371. Grand Forks, ND: The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota
project_metadata.research_context: Methodological case study examining the cooperative deployment of the FAIMS (Federated Archaeological Information Management Systems) mobile platform across three archaeological projects in Turkey, Malawi, and Peru. The paper analyses the co-development process between archaeologists and software developers, examining trade-offs between features and performance, the benefits of generalised versus bespoke software solutions, and the payoffs of upfront investment in digital recording systems.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS project initially funded by NeCTAR eResearch Tools program grant RT043 for AUD $949,500 in 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: It was initially based at the University of New South Wales, Sydney, and funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS mobile platform entered public beta release in November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data (the 'FAIMS mobile platform,' discussed below), which entered public beta release in November 2013.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS received ARC LIEF award LE140100151 totalling AUD $945,000 in 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2014, the FAIMS project received an Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF) award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS 2.0 production version released November 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

evidence.evidence_text: Service fees account for about 5% of FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting 95%
evidence.verbatim_quote: To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%

evidence.evidence_text: In-kind contributions at Macquarie University total approximately $100,000 per year
evidence.verbatim_quote: although these figures exclude in-kind contributions of time by academic staff and other participants, which, for example, total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS team has created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 in the field since November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013. That number is likely to double by the end of 2017.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Two doctoral student projects have successfully customised and deployed their own FAIMS systems
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two small projects, both undertaken by doctoral students, have successfully customised and deployed their own systems.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Pre-configured local server with hardware costs AUD $1,700-$3,500
evidence.verbatim_quote: Purchasing a pre-configured local server with all necessary hardware costs AUD $1,700–$3,500 from one of these vendors (excluding tablets).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Online or local server can be leased for approximately AUD $150-$200 per month
evidence.verbatim_quote: Alternatively, an online or local server can be leased for approximately AUD $150–$200 per month.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Customisation service costs AUD $1,500-$15,000 per season depending on complexity
evidence.verbatim_quote: When a project hires the FAIMS team to adapt an existing module or develop a new one, this service generally costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season for the mobile platform, depending on the complexity and novelty of the recording system required.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu first year customisation valued at about $15,000; subsequent deployment cost $3,250
evidence.verbatim_quote: Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each for their first year of deployment (but only $3,250 for a subsequent deployment for Boncuklu).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC first year cost only $900 by reusing existing module; subsequent deployment $2,400
evidence.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900 (a subsequent deployment cost $2,400, after they identified some additional modifications)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: All FAIMS project software is free and open source under GPLv3 licence
evidence.verbatim_quote: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses GitHub for publishing and managing individual modules
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project uses GitHub, an online version control tool for collaborative software development, to publish and manage individual modules (https://github.com/FAIMS)

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu involves extremely fine layering with single context resolved within less than 5cm of deposit
evidence.verbatim_quote: One peculiarity of the site is its extremely fine layering and the complex intercutting of archaeological features... [a single context in] Boncuklu may be resolved within <5 cm of deposit.

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reports only three iterations of excavation module and two iterations of survey module needed before functional system
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ultimately only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed in the field.

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh's module produced in approximately three and a half weeks from first contact to deployment
evidence.verbatim_quote: The total time that elapsed between first contact with FAIMS leadership and deployment of the finished PAZC module was approximately three and a half weeks.

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC module Spanish translation and customisation required less than one week after requirements fully specified
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn found significant app design problem slipped through checks and required live update in field
evidence.verbatim_quote: A significant problem with the app design has arisen. It is one that I flagged earlier but somehow it got through my later checks...

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn reports record input slowed from 20 minutes initially to over an hour due to syncing and updating issues
evidence.verbatim_quote: More serious was the slowdown of the system halfway through its period of use. A record which initially took 20 minutes to input took over an hour due to slow syncing and updating.

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh reports universal feedback that FAIMS data entry took longer than previous analogue system
evidence.verbatim_quote: While we have yet to keep time-on-task records for either paper-based recording or FAIMS, project members universally reported that data entry using FAIMS took longer than using our previous analogue system.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn received CSV data files before paper forms arrived in Australia
evidence.verbatim_quote: [I have received the CSV file and] the data are present and useable. I am now waiting for [the other project director] to send me the forms...

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn quantifies 95% labour saving: 1-1.5 days handling time with FAIMS versus 25-30 days without
evidence.verbatim_quote: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn estimates savings of AUD $5,000-10,000 per annum in paid RA time
evidence.verbatim_quote: This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn's post-processing took 2-3 hours versus several hundred hours for entry of over 300 context records
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season.

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reports tablets saved at least eight person-days of work for survey team
evidence.verbatim_quote: When the scope of data entry, cleaning, analysis, and archiving is considered, the tablets saved at least eight person-days of work, although this may have been an extreme case

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reports at least six person-hours spent investigating and rectifying transcription errors from previous seasons
evidence.verbatim_quote: nor did they suffer from the inevitable transcription error that in this case cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify.

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh reports improved richness and integrity of data with more detailed context descriptions
evidence.verbatim_quote: our final review of data collected by the PAZC in 2014 suggests that using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data. Context descriptions are generally more detailed

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh reports FAIMS default module fields meant data types previously treated inconsistently were now recorded consistently
evidence.verbatim_quote: the range of fields in the FAIMS default module meant that project members recorded types of data (such as parameters of soil matrices and inclusions) that we had formerly treated in an inconsistent fashion.

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reports FAIMS data outputs required much less cleaning and organisation than transcribed data
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS data outputs [...] required [...] much less cleaning, organisation, and streamlining for consistency than transcribed data.

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh's online server upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps - too slow for syncing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using this system, our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight.

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh unable to complete syncs even on weekend trips to city one hour away due to photograph file sizes
evidence.verbatim_quote: [I] then attempted to sync tablets on weekend trips to a city located one hour's drive away from Zaña. However, the large numbers of photographs we were attaching to our data records made complete syncs impossible.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn reports wifi provided excellent coverage at 75-80% signal strength at 80m distance
evidence.verbatim_quote: the [wifi] provided excellent coverage (75–80% signal strength at 80m, the furthest excavation trench.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn's FAIMS-in-a-box equipment survived dusty conditions and unreliable electricity with only one cracked tablet screen
evidence.verbatim_quote: the equipment—FAIMS-in-a-box—worked very well and with the exception of 1 tablet screen—cracked when an item fell on it from the edge of the trench—came through the season in great condition. This was in spite of very dusty conditions and a somewhat unreliable electricity supply.

claims.claim_text: The FAIMS project was established as a university-based e-research initiative to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative that was launched in 2012 to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS sustainability relies primarily on iterative applications for research infrastructure funding through ARC LIEF program
claims.verbatim_quote: The sustainability plan of the FAIMS project involves iterative applications for research infrastructure funding, primarily through the ARC LIEF program.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS developed a generalised mobile platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data collection that works offline with multiple users
claims.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data

claims.claim_text: FAIMS project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions even as service fees grow
claims.verbatim_quote: We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS has achieved significant adoption with 19 workflows for 17 projects and 11 supported in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: FAIMS adoption is expected to double by end of 2017
claims.verbatim_quote: That number is likely to double by the end of 2017.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Users with sufficient time and expertise can implement FAIMS themselves without purchasing services
claims.verbatim_quote: Users with the time and expertise can implement FAIMS themselves, or they can purchase that service from the FAIMS team.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: FAIMS offers purpose-built field-recording software at reasonable cost to projects that otherwise could not afford bespoke development
claims.verbatim_quote: It is our hope that by building free and open-source software to high standards using research infrastructure funding... we can deliver purpose-built field-recording software to projects and organisations who otherwise could not afford it.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Redeployment of existing modules is significantly cheaper than initial development
claims.verbatim_quote: Deployments of a module for subsequent seasons are usually less expensive because users only pay for changes and support.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Willingness to reuse existing modules offers significant cost savings
claims.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900... illustrating the savings that redeployment can offer.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Open-source approach allows modules to be downloaded, edited, copied, and adapted freely
claims.verbatim_quote: Software or other text documents stored on GitHub can be downloaded, edited, copied, and adapted at will.

claims.claim_text: Building a growing library of modules that accommodate various archaeological activities is a guiding principle of FAIMS
claims.verbatim_quote: It has been a guiding principle of FAIMS to build a growing library of modules that accommodate as many archaeological activities, and variations of them, as possible.

claims.claim_text: Boncuklu's fine layering and complex feature intercutting required fine-grained single context recording method
claims.verbatim_quote: As a result, excavation has necessarily been fine-grained, utilising a single context recording method better to understand the subtle interrelationships of the site's building sequences and extra-mural areas.

claims.claim_text: Established projects with stable procedures have an advantage during software customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Established projects with stable procedures have an advantage during software customisation, since they can articulate requirements and priorities quickly and coherently.

claims.claim_text: Fewer development iterations needed when data categories and relationships worked out in previous paper-based seasons
claims.verbatim_quote: this was likely because all of the data categories and relationships had been worked out—in paper version—over the course of previous field seasons.

claims.claim_text: A generalised system can spawn new deployments rapidly in ways neither bespoke nor general-purpose systems can
claims.verbatim_quote: As this example illustrates, a system with a generalised core can spawn new deployments rapidly in a way that neither bespoke nor general-purpose systems can.

claims.claim_text: Testing the module prior to fieldwork ensured technical functionality and allowed communication of changes
claims.verbatim_quote: Testing the module prior to fieldwork ensured it was technically functional, and allowed for communication of changes that would be hard done remotely

claims.claim_text: All project directors tested their modules ahead of fieldwork but eventually regretted not doing so more thoroughly
claims.verbatim_quote: All project directors tested their modules ahead of fieldwork, but eventually they all regretted not doing so more thoroughly, with more participants, and in more authentic situations.

claims.claim_text: Complex auto-generated context numbers that conform to legacy systems cause significant performance degradation
claims.verbatim_quote: While FAIMS did automatically generate such identifiers, doing so slowed performance... Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew

claims.claim_text: Performance degradation worsened as a square function of the number of records
claims.verbatim_quote: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew (more precisely, as a square function of the number of records).

claims.claim_text: Digital data improvements came at cost of less efficient data collection in the field compared to analogue
claims.verbatim_quote: These improvements (digital data) have come at a cost—namely, less efficient data collection in the field.

claims.claim_text: Upfront investment in digital recording shifts time from backend digitisation to frontend development and testing
claims.verbatim_quote: One of the themes that emerged from these case studies involves the shift in time and energy from digitisation and cleansing of data at the end of the project, to scoping, development, and testing of recording systems at the beginning of the project.

claims.claim_text: Digital data was available immediately at end of fieldwork without tedious digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: an entire season's data could be retrieved immediately, without tedious digitisation and the errors it inevitably introduces

claims.claim_text: Time savings at end of project were substantial even considering up-front time requirement
claims.verbatim_quote: Even considering the up-front time requirement, however, time savings at the end of the project were substantial—even revolutionary

claims.claim_text: Tablets presented huge advantage over paper by tying data together and eliminating transcription error
claims.verbatim_quote: When the survey data were examined and analysed during post-season work, it became very clear to the survey team that the tablets presented a huge advantage.

claims.claim_text: Digital recording eliminates transcription errors that occur with paper-based systems
claims.verbatim_quote: nor did they suffer from the inevitable transcription error that in this case cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify.

claims.claim_text: Digital recording improves both richness and integrity of field data
claims.verbatim_quote: using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data

claims.claim_text: Structured digital forms ensure data types previously treated inconsistently are now recorded consistently
claims.verbatim_quote: the range of fields in the FAIMS default module meant that project members recorded types of data... that we had formerly treated in an inconsistent fashion.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS data outputs require much less cleaning and organisation than transcribed data
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS data outputs [...] required [...] much less cleaning, organisation, and streamlining for consistency than transcribed data.

claims.claim_text: Online servers are unreliable in remote fieldwork settings due to bandwidth limitations
claims.verbatim_quote: His subsequent problems demonstrate the unreliability of the Internet in fieldwork settings

claims.claim_text: Local dedicated hardware servers are more reliable and faster than online servers despite higher cost
claims.verbatim_quote: Local, dedicated hardware servers are more expensive than online servers, and they require that users test and maintain them, but they are faster and more robust than online servers.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS-in-a-box hardware performed well under challenging field conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: the equipment—FAIMS-in-a-box—worked very well... in spite of very dusty conditions and a somewhat unreliable electricity supply.

claims.claim_text: Generalised software allows archaeologists to participate in software development rather than just consume software
claims.verbatim_quote: generalised tools also allow archaeologists to participate in software development, not merely consume software

claims.claim_text: Co-development involves partnership between field archaeologists and software development team
claims.verbatim_quote: Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team. This partnership can ease the transitions from paper to digital fieldwork, illuminate the advantages digital approaches offer, and ensure that software is fit-to-purpose.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS lies near middle of spectrum between consumer-grade general-purpose DBMS and bespoke software development
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS lies near the middle of this spectrum.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS was purpose built to perform well under difficult field conditions with functionality specifically requested by archaeologists
claims.verbatim_quote: It is not general-purpose, however, in that it has been purpose built to perform well under difficult field conditions and includes functionality specifically requested by archaeologists

claims.claim_text: FAIMS devices can operate offline and synchronise whenever Wi-Fi available, accommodating intermittent network conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: devices running FAIMS have no need for a continuous connection to maintain data integrity; they happily operate offline and synchronise whenever a Wi-Fi network is available

claims.claim_text: FileMaker was designed for everyone whereas FAIMS was developed around expressed requirements of archaeologists
claims.verbatim_quote: FileMaker was designed for everyone; FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage the high-friction environment of fieldwork.

claims.claim_text: Bespoke apps may outperform FAIMS for single tasks but at considerable cost beyond resources of most projects
claims.verbatim_quote: A bespoke Android or iOS app, if properly resourced and designed, may outperform FAIMS for any single data collection task, but at considerable cost. The requirements gathering, planning, development, and testing required to produce software reliable enough for field archaeology are expensive and demanding.

claims.claim_text: Shared core FAIMS library allows fixed development and maintenance costs to be distributed across many users
claims.verbatim_quote: Because the core FAIMS software is common to all deployments, however, the fixed costs of development and maintenance can be shared across many users, projects, and institutions.

claims.claim_text: Converting from paper to digital workflows requires making implicit knowledge in paper forms explicit
claims.verbatim_quote: Converting from paper to digital workflows is an involved and time-consuming process. It requires making the implicit knowledge embedded in paper forms explicit.

claims.claim_text: Digital forms must be more precise and complete than paper forms or their primary advantage is lost
claims.verbatim_quote: digital forms must be more precise and complete, or their primary advantage—the production of clean, consistent data—is lost.

claims.claim_text: Conversion from paper to digital often instigates thorough review and revision of existing recording procedures
claims.verbatim_quote: The conversion from fuzzy paper forms to sharp digital recording often instigates a thorough review and revision of existing recording procedures and workflows.

claims.claim_text: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field, especially software that is purpose-built for the research community

claims.claim_text: High-quality and timely support provides peace of mind necessary for archaeologists to risk moving from commercial software to new purpose-built systems
claims.verbatim_quote: Only the availability of high-quality and timely support can provide the peace of mind necessary for archaeologists to risk moving from commercial software to new systems designed specifically for our domain.

claims.claim_text: Digital recording preserves previously undocumented interim steps of fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: Fairbairn also noted how digital recording preserved previously undocumented interim steps of fieldwork... 'we have had a very archaic use of "official site photos" which are of the cleaned up contexts. Well, now everyone can take images as they go'

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: More continuous recordkeeping may improve reproducibility and professionalism of field research
claims.verbatim_quote: More continuous recordkeeping, including of 'messy' work-in-progress, not only helps researchers at a later time better understand what they have excavated, but may contribute toward both making workflows more transparent and 'openly exposing the process of research'

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: Digital recording may not immediately alter researchers' aims or interpretive agendas
claims.verbatim_quote: Digital data collection may not immediately alter researchers' aims or interpretive agendas. Fairbairn began his response to questions about impact by observing that 'so far conversion [to digital recording] has not changed our substantive research goals.'

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: Full impact of digital recording may not be realised until after post-fieldwork analysis and data publication
claims.verbatim_quote: VanValkenburgh noted that the full impact of digital recording would not be clear until after post-fieldwork analysis and integration were complete... It is perhaps at the comparative or synthetic level, beyond individual projects, that we should seek the greatest interpretive impact.

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS strikes good balance between re-deployability of general-purpose software and domain-specific capability of bespoke applications
claims.verbatim_quote: The authors of this paper believe that FAIMS strikes a good balance between the re-deployability of general-purpose database software and the domain- and project-specific capability of bespoke applications.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Archaeological fieldwork generates data types (structured, free-text, geospatial, multimedia) that cannot be adequately captured by general-purpose software designed for office environments
trigger_text: devices running FAIMS have no need for a continuous connection to maintain data integrity; they happily operate offline
FileMaker was designed for everyone; FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage the high-friction environment of fieldwork
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper repeatedly contrasts FAIMS's field-specific features with general-purpose software limitations, implying that archaeology has unique data collection requirements that justify purpose-built solutions

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: The time and cost savings from digital recording are sufficient to justify the upfront investment in software development and training
trigger_text: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving
This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents quantified savings but does not account for all upfront costs (training, testing, developer time), assuming the net benefit is positive without comprehensive cost-benefit analysis

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Archaeological projects have the capacity to invest significant time in software customisation before fieldwork begins
trigger_text: field projects with complex workflows still require several months for development to ensure that the end product satisfies their needs
Consider your recording needs in depth well before deployment of your module
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper recommends months of preparation time without acknowledging that many projects operate on tight schedules or may lack personnel for extended pre-fieldwork software development

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Open-source software can achieve sustainability through a combination of grants, service fees, and in-kind contributions
trigger_text: We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions
To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The sustainability model assumes continued availability of research infrastructure grants, which is not guaranteed given funding cycles and policy changes

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: User feedback from three case studies can be generalised to represent the broader archaeological community's experience with digital recording systems
trigger_text: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork
Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes
Three Case Studies and Three Themes

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents three case studies as evidence for general claims about co-development benefits, though the sample is small and all participants had direct involvement with the FAIMS team

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: The performance problems experienced with FAIMS were primarily due to design choices (like legacy context numbering) rather than fundamental software limitations
trigger_text: This slowdown was avoidable because the actual information encoded in the context identifier can be captured in ways that do not compromise performance
In 2015, both continuing projects (Fairbairn's and VanValkenburgh's) chose simpler context numbering approaches
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper attributes performance issues to user-requested features rather than exploring whether the core platform had inherent performance limitations

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Software testing in controlled environments cannot fully predict performance under actual field conditions
trigger_text: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew
Hardware can cause its own problems, such as device-specific bugs. Software that worked during internal testing by the FAIMS team... did not always work on different tablets
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper acknowledges testing limitations but continues to recommend thorough testing without addressing how to simulate field conditions effectively

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: The FAIMS team's assessment of their own software is objective despite their vested interest in the platform's success
trigger_text: The authors of this paper believe that FAIMS strikes a good balance between the re-deployability of general-purpose database software and the domain- and project-specific capability of bespoke applications
three project directors who co-developed and deployed a FAIMS recording system in collaboration with the FAIMS team report their experiences
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Three of six authors are FAIMS team members, yet the paper presents FAIMS favourably without extensive disclosure of potential conflicts of interest or comparison with alternative platforms

research_designs.design_description: Comparative case study approach examining three archaeological projects (Boncuklu in Turkey, MEMSAP in Malawi, PAZC in Peru) that deployed FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork, with data collected through structured interviews and correspondence with project directors
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork... Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes

research_designs.design_description: Reflective evaluation of the co-development process between FAIMS software team and archaeological project directors, examining how collaborative customisation affects software fitness-for-purpose
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team. This partnership can ease the transitions from paper to digital fieldwork, illuminate the advantages digital approaches offer, and ensure that software is fit-to-purpose.

research_designs.design_description: Comparative analysis of FAIMS deployment approaches across three sites with varying contexts (excavation vs survey, Turkey vs Africa vs Peru, local server vs online server)
trigger_text: Fairbairn's project, based primarily at a Turkish excavation site, presented contrasting problems... Thompson's project, based in Malawi, faced different challenges... VanValkenburgh's project in Peru
research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper systematically contrasts deployment experiences across sites with different characteristics, though this comparative design is not explicitly stated as a research design

research_designs.design_description: Evaluation of costs (customisation, hardware, training) versus benefits (time savings, data quality) of FAIMS deployment across projects
research_designs.verbatim_quote: One of the themes that emerged from these case studies involves the shift in time and energy from digitisation and cleansing of data at the end of the project, to scoping, development, and testing of recording systems at the beginning of the project.

research_designs.design_description: Organisation of case study observations into three thematic categories: upfront costs/backend payouts, trade-offs between features and performance, and digital recording's impact on interpretation
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes

methods.method_description: Collection of experiences and observations from project directors through structured questions and email correspondence during and after 2014 fieldwork
methods.verbatim_quote: The first-hand perspective is useful: while the authors affiliated with FAIMS can observe and analyse deployments, only field directors who use FAIMS are in a position to relate their experiences and assess relative benefits and shortcomings.

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes

methods.method_description: Systematic comparison of deployment experiences across three sites with different characteristics (site type, geographic location, infrastructure availability)
trigger_text: All three projects were established undertakings... However, each experienced the customisation process differently
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper compares experiences across sites but does not explicitly name this as a formal comparative method

methods.method_description: Organisation of diverse observations from three case studies into coherent thematic categories that capture cross-cutting patterns
methods.verbatim_quote: Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes

methods.method_description: Documentation of the iterative customisation process between FAIMS team and project directors, including requirements gathering, module development, testing, and deployment support
methods.verbatim_quote: Customising a recording module begins with scoping, in which a project specifies the information it wants to record and the workflows best suited to producing that information.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

methods.method_description: Comparison of local server versus online server performance across different deployment contexts and network conditions
trigger_text: Local, dedicated hardware servers are more expensive than online servers, and they require that users test and maintain them, but they are faster and more robust than online servers.
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper compares infrastructure options based on project experiences but does not formally describe this as a method

methods.method_description: Estimation and comparison of time required for data handling with digital versus paper-based recording systems
methods.verbatim_quote: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum

methods.method_description: Documentation of customisation and deployment costs across projects with different requirements and approaches
methods.verbatim_quote: Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each for their first year of deployment

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

protocols.protocol_description: Structured questions posed to project directors about their FAIMS deployment experiences, covering scoping, testing, field use, and post-fieldwork outcomes
trigger_text: VanValkenburgh, for example, explained
Fairbairn began his response to questions about impact by observing
Thompson reports

trigger_locations.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper quotes project directors responding to questions but does not provide the explicit interview protocol used

protocols.protocol_description: Collection and analysis of email exchanges between FAIMS team and project directors during deployment process
protocols.verbatim_quote: A significant problem with the app design has arisen. It is one that I flagged earlier but somehow it got through my later checks...

protocols.protocol_description: Framework for comparing deployment contexts across sites based on project type, location, infrastructure, and recording requirements
trigger_text: Fairbairn's project, based primarily at a Turkish excavation site, presented contrasting problems
Thompson's project, based in Malawi
VanValkenburgh's project in Peru
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper systematically describes each site's characteristics but does not provide an explicit comparison framework

protocols.protocol_description: Process for identifying and organising cross-cutting themes from case study observations
trigger_text: Their observations can be woven into three themes

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes

protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper presents three themes but does not describe the analytical process used to identify and define them

protocols.protocol_description: Process for gathering and specifying project recording requirements through forms review and stakeholder consultation
protocols.verbatim_quote: Customising a recording module begins with scoping, in which a project specifies the information it wants to record and the workflows best suited to producing that information. This process usually begins with FAIMS examining a project's existing paper forms, if available.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

protocols.protocol_description: Iterative process of module customisation including XML schema creation, UI design, and testing cycles
protocols.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified.

protocols.protocol_description: Testing of customised modules prior to field deployment to verify functionality
protocols.verbatim_quote: Testing the module prior to fieldwork ensured it was technically functional, and allowed for communication of changes that would be hard done remotely

protocols.protocol_description: Monitoring and documenting server synchronisation performance including upload speeds and sync completion rates
trigger_text: Using this system, our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps
the [wifi] provided excellent coverage (75–80% signal strength at 80m
protocols.inference_reasoning: Performance data is reported but the monitoring protocol is not explicitly described

protocols.protocol_description: Estimation of time spent on data handling tasks with and without FAIMS system
protocols.verbatim_quote: a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving

protocols.protocol_description: Documentation of customisation service costs, hardware costs, and ongoing support costs for each deployment
protocols.verbatim_quote: When a project hires the FAIMS team to adapt an existing module or develop a new one, this service generally costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

persistent_identifiers.notes: Paper is a book chapter without DOI. No author ORCIDs provided. Software repository URL explicitly mentioned for FAIMS modules.

sources.funder: Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR)

sources.notes: Total ARC funding and university co-investment

funding.acknowledgement_text: The FAIMS project received funding from NeCTAR eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500) and ARC LIEF award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000). In-kind contributions from participating universities total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone.

machine_actionability.rationale: No data availability statement present. Case study data (interview transcripts, email correspondence) not deposited in any repository.

code_availability.documentation: Modules published via GitHub with version control

machine_actionability.rationale: Software repository URL provided and licence specified. However, no DOI for software versions, no specific release tags mentioned for versions used in case studies.

author_contributions.notes: No formal CReDIT statement. Author roles can be inferred: Sobotkova, Ross, Ballsun-Stanton are FAIMS team members; Fairbairn, Thompson, VanValkenburgh are case study project directors who provided deployment experiences.

conflicts_of_interest.notes: No COI statement. Three of six authors (Sobotkova, Ross, Ballsun-Stanton) are directly affiliated with FAIMS project being evaluated.

ethics_approval.notes: No ethics statement. Paper describes software deployment experiences, not human subjects research in traditional sense, though interview/correspondence data from project directors was collected.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Not applicable to this methodological paper. Individual archaeological projects (Boncuklu, MEMSAP, PAZC) would have their own excavation permits but these are not the focus of this paper.

preregistration.notes: Methodological case study - preregistration not expected for this study type

supplementary_materials.notes: No supplementary materials mentioned. Interview protocols, email correspondence, and detailed case study data not provided.

fair_assessment.assessment_notes: Findable: Book chapter in open access volume but no DOI. Accessible: Published open access, software on GitHub. Interoperable: Software uses standard formats but no formal data standards documented. Reusable: Software is open source (GPLv3) but case study data not available for reuse.

pass0_metadata.notes: Book chapter in edited volume. Six authors: three FAIMS team members (Sobotkova, Ross, Ballsun-Stanton) and three case study project directors (Fairbairn, Thompson, VanValkenburgh). No DOI - published as open access by The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota.

pass1_evidence_claims.notes: Liberal extraction of evidence from case study descriptions and quantitative data. Claims include methodological arguments about co-development and empirical observations about deployment outcomes.

pass3_rdmap.notes: RDMAP extraction identified case study design, co-development evaluation, and thematic analysis as primary research designs. Methods include qualitative data collection and cost-benefit analysis. Several protocols are implicit.

pass6_infrastructure.notes: Strong funding documentation with grant numbers and amounts. Software available on GitHub under GPLv3. No data availability statement - case study data (interviews, correspondence) not deposited.

known_limitations: No comparison with alternative digital recording platforms
Case study data not available for independent verification
